Class Loop

java.lang.Object
net.tp.utils.classes.Loop
public abstract class Loop extends Object
A class for loops.

1.0.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Runnable runnable)
      Loops the given Runnable until a Loop.Break is thrown. For throw a Loop.Break use breakLoop().
      Parameters:
      runnable - The Runnable to loop.
      Since:
      1.0.0

    • breakAndReturn

      public static <V> void breakAndReturn(V value)
      Returns the given value and breaks the current loop.
      Type Parameters:
      V - The type of the value.
      Parameters:
      value - The value to return.
      Since:
      1.0.0
      See Also:
      • loop(Supplier)

    • continueLoop

      public static Loop.Continue continueLoop()
      Continue the current loop.
      Since:
      1.0.0
      See Also:
      • loop(Supplier)

    • loop

      public static <T extends Loop.LoopTypes, V> V loop(Supplier<T> supplier)
      Loops the given Supplier until a breakAndReturn(Object) is returned. Continue the loop with continueLoop().

      Always end the loop with: 

      
 {
     ...
     return continueLoop();
 });
      Type Parameters:
      T - The type of the Supplier.
      V - The type of the value to return.
      Parameters:
      supplier - The Supplier to loop.
      Returns:
      The value returned by the breakAndReturn(Object).
      Since:
      1.0.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Consumer<Integer> action, int start, int steps, int times)
      Executes the given Consumer a given number of times.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
     for (int i = start; i < start + times * steps; i+= steps) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      start - The initial value of the lambda integer.
      steps - The number of steps to increment the lambda integer.
      times - The number of times to execute the Consumer.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Consumer<Integer> action, int start, int times)
      Executes the given Consumer a given number of times.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
     for (int i = start; i < times; i++) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      start - The initial value of the lambda integer.
      times - The number of times to execute the Consumer.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Consumer<Integer> action, int times)
      Executes the given Consumer a given number of times.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
     for (int i = 0; i < times; i++) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      times - The number of times to execute the Consumer.
      Since:
      1.0.0

    • loopRange

      public static void loopRange(Consumer<Integer> action, int start, int end, boolean closed, int steps)
      Executes the given Consumer until reach end.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
    for (int i = start; i <= end; i += steps) { ... }
      for closed range, otherwise: 
      
   for (int i = start; i < end; i += steps) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      start - The initial value of the lambda integer.
      end - The final value of the lambda integer.
      closed - If the range is closed.
      steps - The number of steps to increment the lambda integer.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loopRange

      public static void loopRange(Consumer<Integer> action, int end, boolean closed, int steps)
      Executes the given Consumer until reach end.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
    for (int i = 0; i <= end; i += steps) { ... }
      for 0 range, otherwise: 
      
   for (int i = start; i < end; i += steps) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      end - The final value of the lambda integer.
      closed - If the range is closed.
      steps - The number of steps to increment the lambda integer.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loopRange

      public static void loopRange(Consumer<Integer> action, int end, boolean closed)
      Executes the given Consumer until reach end.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
    for (int i = 0; i <= end; i++) { ... }
      for 0 range, otherwise: 
      
   for (int i = start; i < end; i++) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      end - The final value of the lambda integer.
      closed - If the range is closed.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loopRange

   for (int i = start; i < end; i+= steps) { ... }
      Parameters:

    • loopRange

      public static void loopRange(Consumer<Integer> action, int start, int end, boolean closed)
      Executes the given Consumer a number until reach end.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
    for (int i = start; i <= end; i++) { ... }
      for closed range, otherwise: 
      
   for (int i = start; i < end; i++) { ... }
      Parameters:
      action - The Consumer to execute.
      start - The initial value of the lambda integer.
      end - The final value of the lambda integer.
      closed - If the range is closed.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Supplier<Boolean> condition, Runnable action)
      Loops the given Runnable until the given condition is met.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
     while (!condition) {
         ...
     }
      Parameters:
      condition - The condition to check.
      action - The Runnable to loop.
      Since:
      1.2.0

    • loop

      public static void loop(Runnable action, Supplier<Boolean> condition)
      Loops the given Runnable until the given condition is met. The first run is always made.

      An equivalent sequence of increasing values can be produced sequentially using a for loop as follows: 

      
     do {
         ...
     } while (!condition);
      Parameters:
      action - The Runnable to loop.
      condition - The condition to check.
      Since:
      1.2.0
